page.title: 07THORNHILL THE STIRLING CARSE
page.content: The Carse of Stirling was carved out during the ice-age.When the glaciers melted,the land was below sea level.The sea came in and covered the land and when it retreated,it left a cover of rich alluvial soil.The carse, therefore,is very wide,flat and fertile.It is famous for growing Timothy hay,the best of this heavy crop being sold for seed.Other crops grown are wheat and barley.The River Forth meanders across the carse and the Goodie Water flows into it about three and a half miles east of our block.The village of Thornhill sits above the carse,looking down over it. Netherton and Norrieston farms are typical carse farms.About September, flocks of geese arrive from the Tundra lands of the north to spend the winter.The carse is approx.10 miles long and averages 4 miles in width.
